sections.theme: Purpose of Revelation and Life's Test
sections.summary: Allah reveals the Book to provide **good news** to believers and warn those who claim Allah has a **son**. The world and its contents are described as an **ornament** and a **test** of conduct before being reduced to waste [223–224].

A group of youths take shelter in a cave to protect their faith in **Divine Oneness**, where Allah seals their ears for three hundred and nine years. The narrative emphasizes Allah's power over **resurrection** and instructs believers to always link future intentions to **Allah's will** [224–226].

The Messenger is commanded to recite the **Book** and remain patient with those who call upon their Lord. It contrasts the **Fire** awaiting the unjust with the **Gardens of Eden** promised to those who lead a righteous life.

sections.theme: The Parable of the Two Gardens
sections.summary: An account of two men illustrates the danger of **arrogance** linked to material wealth and manpower. The destruction of the ungrateful man's harvest demonstrates that absolute **authority** and reward belong only to Allah [226–227].

sections.theme: Transience of Life and the Record
sections.summary: The **worldly life** is likened to vegetation that flourishes and then becomes scattered debris. On the Day of Judgment, every deed, small or large, will be enumerated in a **Record**, leaving the guilty in terror of their own actions [227–228].

The text recounts **Satan's** refusal to prostrate to Adam and warns against taking him as a lord. It critiques the human tendency toward **argumentation** and notes that Allah’s **mercy** postpones the punishment for towns that commit injustices [228–229].

Moses journeys to the junction of the two rivers to seek guidance from a blessed servant of Allah. Through three challenging events—the damaged boat, the slain boy, and the repaired wall—Moses learns the hidden **wisdom** and **Divine Plan** behind seemingly negative occurrences [229–231].

A powerful leader travels to the extremities of the earth, eventually building an iron and tar **barrier** to protect a weak people from the chaos of **Gog and Magog**. He clarifies that this protection is a **mercy** from his Lord that will eventually be leveled when the promise comes true [231–232].

The surah concludes with the blowing of the Trumpet and the display of Hell for those who took divine signs in **mockery**. It affirms that the **Words of Allah** are infinite and defines the Messenger as a mortal who receives revelation to call humanity to the worship of **One God** [232–233].
